citations.narrative:
In the annex where 3 ring-tailed lemurs are temporarily housed, there are at least 5 horizontal metal support rods along
the bottom of the enclosure with the ends being sharp to the touch, and within reach of the animals. Access to these
sharp points can potentially injure the animals. Housing facilities for nonhuman primates must be designed and
constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of nonhuman primates housed in them. They must be kept
in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury.
To be corrected by 2/2/2024

The following housekeeping issues and/or repairs were noted in several animal areas: In the back of Giant River Otter,
there were at least 3 cobwebs present over the food prep area. Cobwebs were removed at time of inspection. The floor
appears porous in at least one area and may impede the required cleaning. The floor to be corrected by 6/1/2024
In the Veterinary surgery suite, there are at least 3 areas, approximately the size of a dime, where the wall paint has
chipped off and the underlying porous material is exposed. There was a flexible hose attached to the anesthesia machine
with an accumulation of dust and debris. This hose was discarded at time of inspection.
In the small animal holding, approximately half the surface area of the base of an instrument stand had an accumulation
of rust. The facility representative stated it was a discarded item and was removed from the room.
There are at least 2 areas on a wall, approximately 1 inch x 1 inch in size, and a drain grate with chipped paint. The areas
exposed behind the wall damage appear porous and may impede cleaning. Cleaning utensils such as a broom and dust
pan were being stored directly on the ground. The cleaning utensils were corrected at time of inspection.
In the medium animal holding, there are at least 2 areas, approximately 1 inch x 1 inch in size, and an additional area,
approximately 14 inches in length at the base of a wall, where the paint has chipped off and/or buckled under exposing
underlying porous material. A drain grate with chipped paint is also missing a support bar. In the hoof stock holding area,
there are at least 2 areas where wall spaces, varying between 1 inch X 1 - 4 inches in size, and a drain grate have areas
of chipped paint. On the walls, the areas behind the chipped paint appears porous and may impede cleaning. In the
health center keeper kitchen, directly below the countertop, the front edge of the cabinet is in disrepair, exposing raw
wood material. In the health center keeper and quarantine building kitchens, the ceiling tiles are porous and there are
gaps present between at least 2 tiles in each area.
To be corrected by 9/1/2024

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
In the bird show kitchen, there are two areas, approximately 2 ft. X 1 ft. and 1 ft. X .5 ft., where the floor is severely worn
and the underlying porous material is exposed. There are at least 2 storage cabinets where the sealant has worn off and
the underlying raw wood is exposed. Wood is beginning to splinter along the bottom of one cabinet. Worn and damaged
floors and cabinets may impede the required cleaning.
Premises where housing facilities are located, including buildings, surrounding grounds, and exhibit areas, must be kept
clean and in good repair in order to protect the birds from injury and disease, to facilitate the husbandry practices required
in this subpart.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Lemnique Wafer, Assistant Director n

narrative:
3.75(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
In the annex where 3 ring-tailed lemurs are temporarily housed, there are at least 5 horizontal metal support rods along 
the bottom of the enclosure with the ends being sharp to the touch, and within reach of the animals. Access to these

constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of nonhuman primates housed in them. They must be kept 
in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury. 
To be corrected by 2/2/2024 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
The following housekeeping issues and/or repairs were noted in several animal areas: In the back of Giant River Otter, 
there were at least 3 cobwebs present over the food prep area. Cobwebs were removed at time of inspection. The floor 
appears porous in at least one area and may impede the required cleaning. The floor to be corrected by 6/1/2024  
In the Veterinary surgery suite, there are at least 3 areas, approximately the size of a dime, where the wall paint has

with an accumulation of dust and debris. This hose was discarded at time of inspection.  
In the small animal holding, approximately half the surface area of the base of an instrument stand had an accumulation 
of rust. The facility representative stated it was a discarded item and was removed from the room.  
There are at least 2 areas on a wall, approximately 1 inch x 1 inch in size, and a drain grate with chipped paint. The areas 
exposed behind the wall damage appear porous and may impede cleaning. Cleaning utensils such as a broom and dust 
pan were being stored directly on the ground. The cleaning utensils were corrected at time of inspection. 
In the medium animal holding, there are at least 2 areas, approximately 1 inch x 1 inch in size, and an additional area,

gaps present between at least 2 tiles in each area. 
To be corrected by 9/1/2024 
3.158(c)  Repeat
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
In the bird show kitchen, there are two areas, approximately 2 ft. X 1 ft. and 1 ft. X .5 ft., where the floor is severely worn 
and the underlying porous material is exposed. There are at least 2 storage cabinets where the sealant has worn off and 
the underlying raw wood is exposed. Wood is beginning to splinter along the bottom of one cabinet. Worn and damaged 
floors and cabinets may impede the required cleaning. 
Premises where housing facilities are located, including buildings, surrounding grounds, and exhibit areas, must be kept 
clean and in good repair in order to protect the birds from injury and disease, to facilitate the husbandry practices required 
in this subpart. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Lemnique Wafer, Assistant Director n

species.common: AFRICAN HUNTING DOG / AFRICAN WILD DOG
